pullRequest.body:
Lemmas such as `limsup u f + liminf v f â‰¤ limsup (u + v) f` (and its multiplicative avatars) in (basically) reals. These lemmas had already been done in EReal/ENNReal. The strategy is the same; using reals brings some complexity with the gestion of `IsBoundedUnder`/`IsCoboundedUnder` properties.

Summary of the modifications:
* In [Mathlib/Algebra/Order/Group/DenselyOrdered.lean](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/compare/master...D-Thomine/limsup_add_mul#diff-87f5a269787b67b9ec09b3e5d2d10ab4a5cf94fb0ea67087ca8efe323e26d787): proof of `le_mul_of_forall_lt` and `mul_le_of_forall_lt`, as well as their additive versions, which are key for the final results on (R, +).
* In [Mathlib/Algebra/Order/Field/Basic.lean](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/compare/master...D-Thomine/limsup_add_mul#diff-38676ab53a1bf62d5eb4d1a87a4c7607f056a6c13968c1683148ddb178863343): proof of `le_mul_of_forall_lt'` and `mul_le_of_forall_lt_of_nonneg`, which are key for the final results on (R+, *).
* In [Mathlib/Order/LiminfLimsup.lean](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/compare/master...D-Thomine/limsup_add_mul#diff-15958880e4301dca2ca609bc984fb6192aa21a3013677c7ddb10b4d885927026): four lemmas from `IsCobounded.frequently_le` to `IsCobounded.of_frequently_le` are moved to the beginning of the file, so they can be used within. Four new elementary lemmas about `IsBoundedUnder` which I found quite practical. Four new lemmas about boundedness/coboundedness of sums and products.
* In [Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/Order/LiminfLimsup.lean](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/compare/master...D-Thomine/limsup_add_mul#diff-47f3840d4d3e20e25976271e7e13b4542be1cd0c5fd147e72bb1a0736440624b): eight new lemmas about addition/multiplication and limsup/liminfs.

---

```suggestion
lemma IsBoundedUnder.eventually_ge (h : IsBoundedUnder (Â· â‰¥ Â·) f u) : âˆƒ a, âˆ€á¶  x in f, a â‰¤ u x := h

lemma isBoundedUnder_of_eventually_le {a : Î±} (h : âˆ€á¶  x in f, u x â‰¤ a) :
    IsBoundedUnder (Â· â‰¤ Â·) f u := âŸ¨a, hâŸ©

lemma isBoundedUnder_of_eventually_ge {a : Î±} (h : âˆ€á¶  x in f, a â‰¤ u x) :
    IsBoundedUnder (Â· â‰¥ Â·) f u := âŸ¨a, hâŸ©
```
Do you really think we need those four lemmas? They are all true by definition

> They are all true by definition

Not exactly. This works with `IsBounded`, but `IsBoundedUnder` has an additional layer. For instance, something like

`(hu : f.IsBoundedUnder (Â· â‰¤ Â·) u); obtain âŸ¨U, hUâŸ© := hu`

yields `hU : âˆ€á¶  (x : R) in map u f, (fun x1 x2 â†¦ x1 â‰¤ x2) x U`, while

`(hu : f.IsBoundedUnder (Â· â‰¤ Â·) u); obtain âŸ¨U, hUâŸ© := hu.eventually_le`

yields `hU : âˆ€á¶  (x : Î±) in f, u x â‰¤ U`, which is more readily useful. There are a couple instances in this new version of `Mathlib.Order.LiminfLimsup` where this is useful (see e.g. the proof of `isCoboundedUnder_ge_add`).

This is not a big change, but I did not find a simple clean solution, and a basic lemma with a dot notation felt intuitive enough.

> something like
> ```
> (hu : f.IsBoundedUnder (Â· â‰¤ Â·) u); obtain âŸ¨U, hUâŸ© := hu
> ```
> yields `hU : âˆ€á¶  (x : R) in map u f, (fun x1 x2 â†¦ x1 â‰¤ x2) x U`, while
> ```
> (hu : f.IsBoundedUnder (Â· â‰¤ Â·) u); obtain âŸ¨U, hUâŸ© := hu.eventually_le
> ```
> yields `hU : âˆ€á¶  (x : Î±) in f, u x â‰¤ U`, which is more readily useful.

Yes so the reason for this difference is that `(Â· â‰¤ Â·)` means `fun x1 x2 â†¦ x1 â‰¤ x2`, not `LE.le`. Note that this might change soon, see https://github.com/leanprover/lean4/pull/2267. In the meantime, one could replace `f.IsBoundedUnder (Â· â‰¤ Â·) u` by `f.IsBoundedUnder LE.le u`.

In any case, both these lemmas and this possible spelling change are scope-creep for this PR. Please remove them and open another PR if you really care about them

This is a common case split, so we have a dedicated lemma for it
```suggestion
  obtain tbot | âŸ¨t', ht'âŸ© := isBot_or_exists_lt t
  Â· exact âŸ¨t, .of_forall fun r â†¦ tbot râŸ©
```
Same below
Nice trick. I did some minor additional golfing in the same area (`isBoundedUnder_le_sum`, `isBoundedUnder_ge_sum`).
Do you think you could rewrite this part of the proof using `filter_upwards`, for readability?

I think the main problem is that `filter_upwards` works with eventual goals, and we would like to have it work with frequent goals when you have at most one frequent hypothesis (something I discussed yesterday with Patrick Massot).

In the meantime, it will just be tinkering; I don't see a nice way to use `filter_upwards` (we need to isolate the eventual part of the proof, but then `filter_upwards` already applies `.mono`... Doable, but not sure it would be more readable).

As a compromise, I broke up the proof term using `refine`s, which makes it easier to understand in tactical state, and easier to modify if such an improvement of `filter_upwards` is done.
Same here
Same issue.
And here and below ðŸ˜±
This one was particularly nasty... Same issue as above.
